trails.name: Carlton Preserve
trails.description:
Trail is now open. This is a new trail system the SCORR (Sarasota Charlotte county Off Road Riders) Just built last spring and has been under water most of the summer. If you want to experience Florida riding at it's best, now is the time. You will get your feet a little wet, it will be 5 challenging miles, you'll get your heart rate up, your bike will get dirty, but you'll end up with a smile on your face.
Carlton Preserve
1800 Mabry Carlton Pkwy, Venice, FL 34292

trails.name: BoldlyGo
trails.description: Flat Singletrack good amount of twists turns and roots.

trails.name: The Celery Fields
trails.description: This trail is great for short rides before or after work. They have cut some new trails along the side that make it so you don't have to walk your bike up the mound the whole time.

trails.name: Tiger Marsh
trails.description: Appears as a loop on the map but about 3 miles in it's a bit over grown.

trails.description: Singletrack, hardpacked- maintained by SCORR riders- restrooms at MCEP park- great singletrack for the area-

trails.name: North Port Mountain Bike Trails
trails.description: Approximately 9 miles of a combination of singletrack, fire trails, technical switchbacks, rocks, and some sand and roots. Most of the trail is intermediate. Some parts of the trail are really advanced. Great Trail for SW Florida.

trails.description: Sandy singletrack for hiking & biking

trails.name: Palmetto Trail
trails.description: First trail, in what will be a series of single-track trails here.  Trail entrance is just off to the right of the park gazebo.  Currently 3.4 miles of what will be 5, to the campsite along the Myakka River. TRAIL IS NOW FINSIHED.  Beautiful views of Myakka River.

trails.description: Single track...easy with a few medium level spots

trails.description: Longest trail through pine flatwoods and scrub

trails.description: Short hike to ancient sand dune overlook

trails.name: East Loop Trail
trails.description: Varied terrain through multiple habitats

trails.name: Jonathan Dickinson State Park
trails.description: It has three levels of difficulty from the novice to the more technical riders. Green is easy, blue is intermediate, and black is hard. Know your limits enjoy. Trail is single track, with roots, jumps, wooden bridges, and switch backs. You can take it easy or make a day of it. Although the trails are short, they offer some nice elevation changes and are designed to be very flowy. During the summer there is pretty much ZERO shade so be prepared. Tortoise and Hare trails are a blast to hammer down and just go. All routes lead back to the main parking lot. Camping in the area is also great, and you can ride the paved trail they have from the campground to the off road sections and add a good amount of miles onto your day.

trails.name: Riverbend
trails.description: Not far from C-18 or the Hungryland Preserve

trails.name: Cypress Creek Natural Area
trails.description: Shell rock road through the Cypress Creek Natural Area. There are a few boardwalks that overlook the natural area and splinter trails for "foot traffic only". Trail goes to 2 miles west to Mac Dairy Rd and ends.

trails.name: Halpatiokee
trails.description: Single track network with some simple ups and downs. Lots of Florida scrub riding. Some sand but mostly loose soil ride. New trails being developed around lakes and along river. Nothing really techical. Good after work ride.

trails.name: Dyer Park
trails.description:
nice..fairly clean..not crowded..two potolets along the way..i learned to ride on the trail
easy, medium and hard parts. over all a nice hour to hour and a half ride.

trails.name: Apoxee Park
trails.description: Fairly Flat and mostly hard packed sand and recycled asphault. Half under canopy and half out in open. Tons of wildlife, Gators , Birds , Turtles , otters , coons and on and on.

trails.name: Owahee Trail
trails.description:
Description: The bikeable perimeter trail follows a levee containing sections of loose sand, dirt, and crushed concrete. The trail connect with both the Apoxee trail and SWA trails.

Wildlife Viewing: Wading birds include snowy egrets, glossy ibis and roseate spoonbills. Alligators are common in the canal while bobcat and deer can sometimes can be sighted on the levee.

Activites: Hiking, wildlife viewing and biking.

Amenities: None

Hours: Dawn-Dusk
Part of East Coast Greenway - Martin Corridor

trails.description: Famous for alligator and bison sightings

trails.name: Gainesville-Hawthorne Trail
trails.description: Paved rail-trail through the prairie

trails.name: Cone's Dike Trail
trails.description: Historic dike with prairie basin views

trails.name: Chacala Trail
trails.description: This is a mostly level trail that goes through Paynes Prairie. It is doubletrack that offers beautiful scenery and a good cardio workout. Although it is level there are long stretches of sugar sand that really give your lungs a workout.

trails.name: Bolen Bluff Trail
trails.description: This trail is a lollipop configuration. You start at the trailhead and you can go either left or right. The doubletrack trail winds through a shady oak forest before going straight out into the prairie. At the end there is an observation platform with nice views.

trails.name: Gainesville-Hawthorne State Trail
trails.description: This is not an MTB trail but it is worth listing because it has over 16 miles of paved car free riding. You will pass through a beautiful forest where you will see wildlife and awesome scenery. This trail is mostly flat but there are a couple of areas where you will encounter a gradual elevation change. A local Gainesville favorite that will give you miles of great biking.

trails.name: Sweetwater Preserve
trails.description: A nice trail that is close to the center of Gainesville. Trail features a little climbing and descending, some tight turns and a couple of log crossings. Typical Florida terrain heresandy in some sections but not to the point that its a pain. This is in an area locals call homeless hills due to some homeless camps in the area. A place worth checking out in Gainesville.

trails.name: Alligator Alley
trails.description: Alligator alley is a nice short trail that takes you alongside Bivens Arm and offers some nice views of the lake.  The singletrack is fairly difficult in some spots due to roots but overall it is rideable by most. The trail has some slight elevation changes here and there. Its fun to ride but its very short. Its usually used to connect you with other trails that are spread out through Gainesville.

trails.name: Fred Bear
trails.description: There are several entrances to the trail, look for sand paths. Great for trials stuff, about a mile, not much on the trails side. Some of this trail has been cut off, so from what I understand, it's even shorter now.

trails.name: Gainesville Dirt Jumps
trails.description:
There are roughly 6 good jump lines,a wall ride, and a few drops and bridges out there that are alot of fun.The area is more like a MTB park than a trail so if you are looking for a good trail ride,you may want to skip this.If you want to feed the gravity monster though,this may be the place.

Please respect the structures and jumps.

trails.name: 20th Ave
trails.description: The trail is mostly singletrack and has a fire road at the end. There is not much elevation change to speak of but there are some sections with roots that might pose a problem to beginners, other than that this trail is great for beginners. If you take a left instead of a right when you come out the nature sanctuary and start taking the fire road you can cross under I-75 and link this trail up with Split Rock for some more miles.

trails.name: Split Rock Trail
trails.description: The trail is a doubletrack/fire road loop that has good out and back singletrack all around it. The trail is mostly beginner with no elevation change or major obstacles. Not much traffic, so it can be a peaceful ride..

trails.name: Creekside
trails.description: Starts with a small slope down at the edge of the parking lot to a fallen tree,there is a one way ramp to a 1.5ft drop but it needs some maintainence on holding it down currently.The trail winds through the thick forest near some houses and streets and then comes through a park with water available.From there it is on and off some roads but gets to a part with a 8ft. wall that elevates the trail for almost half a mile.shortly after that, the trail hops back out on the road and if you follow that, it heads into another trail section that I had never seen and is relatively new.Nice singletrack with a loop around a body of water that I really couldn't see.Nice fun ride and good for a bit over 5 miles out and back.Not too terribly technical but you will find some roots to contend with.

trails.name: 31st Drive
trails.description: Nice little singletrack network with some bridges over the creek. I went when it was dry, but it seemed like if it had rained recently much of it would be under water.

trails.name: Hogtown Creek Greenway
trails.description: This is a short trail, usually very sandy unless it's rained. The "bowl" has little drop offs that are pretty fun, and there's a few trails running a mile or so. Even if it hasn't, there's usually plenty of water to go in :)

trails.name: Esterbrook Trails
trails.description: It's really cool, it has tons of little bridges built all over the place. Lots of little sharp turns and steep mounds and drops. Not a huge place but a fun hour long ride.

trails.name: Razorback
trails.description: There are 2 loops : one short and one long. Plenty of climbs that let you earn your decents. Good fast singlrack. Varied terrain. Worth traveling from South Florida to go there. While in the area try Santos or Hardrock.

trails.name: The Rock Trail
trails.description: Trail starts with some ups and downs with one steep drop. Then it climbs a dirt road before it goes into the woods for several miles of twisty singletrack. There are some open areas with a good grassy climb. This is a new trail and more singletrack will be added in the near future.

trails.name: The Powerlines
trails.description: Once on the trail, go straight. You will reach an open meadow that makes for a screaming downhill - perfect place to tune your suspension. At the bottom fo the first decent, there is a nice open climb to the top of another decent. At the end of the second decent, turn right into the woods. At the "T," go to the right. Follow the trail. There's some really good singletrack in the woods, just look around for it.

trails.name: Hidden Rise
trails.description: This is one of the new trails in San Felasco. You can reach it by a connector off of Pine for You. The trail has a good mix of pine forest, climbs, descents, and tight singletrack. Great addition to San Felasco.

trails.name: Pine For You
trails.description: The trail is all the way in the back of San felasco and it is a good ride just to get there. The trail goes through a pine forest and the secluded feeling is great. There are a few climbs and descents but mostly flat singletrack.

trails.name: Conquistador
trails.description: This trail is a lung buster. the trail is comprised of climbs and decents that will test you fitness level. The downhills are fast and fun and the climbs are steep for Florida. It is located behind Tung Nut and Hammock Hub

trails.name: San Felasco Hammock Preserve
trails.description: This is the truest XC trail in Florida, lots of distance with continuous gradual up and down grades. The whole trail is fine for anyone with just a little experience from a technical standpoint, when the trail describes beginner, intermediate, or difficult it is referring to the lungs you need to complete the hills. Very enjoyable. The trail is all network and small loops so you can easily ride 3 miles or 30 miles as your heart desires. Park is gorgeous in the trails except a little sun exposure on Tug Nut.

trails.name: Tung Nut Loop
trails.description: You will need some lungs for this loop, lots of steep climbs and drops that will give you a great workout. The downhills are short but sweet and the scenery is great. The trail offers a little bit of everything as you pass over hills, open fields and hammocks.

trails.name: Meadow View
trails.description: This is a good trail for beginners to get some good miles in. There are not really any obstacles or elevation changes that would cause any trouble, just nice mostly flat singletrack that can be an out and back or linked with Tung Nut loop for extra miles and more of a challenge.

trails.name: Cellon Creek Loop
trails.description: A nice loop in San Felasco. Over 4 miles of nicely maintained singletrack. There are some gradual elevation changes but nothing that even new riders can't handle. The trail loops around a creek so there is plenty of nice scenery.

trails.name: Cottontail
trails.description: Easy beginner trail, starts fast then tightens up as you go, very little elevation.

trails.description: Part of Archer Road Corridor

trails.description: Part of Archer Braid Trail

trails.description: Part of Palatka to Hawthorne Corridor

trails.description: Part of Palatka to Hawthorne Corridor

trails.name: Sand Lake Trail
trails.description: Diverse habitats including sandhills and wetlands

trails.name: Rock Springs Run Trail
trails.description: Remote trail along Rock Springs Run

trails.name: Wekiwa Springs State Park
trails.description:
Its a loop, but head west out of the parking area to access the bike trail.  It doesn't look like a trail, and the sign warns authorized vehicles only.  The singletrack portion of the trail is a little further down the trail and doubles as a hiking trail, but the senic diversity of the trail make running into the occational hiker well worth it.  You also have a great chance of seeing some wildlife.  Be aware of the red blazes that mark the trail, as you will easily get lost if you are not careful.  Once the shared trail ends, in order the continue the loop, one is forced onto a fire road/break.  Why this is a designated bike trail I'll never know.  Deep ruts and huge clods of dirt make riding impossible except on the edge of the bush.  You'll inevitibly end up walking your bike through the worst of it.  
The bicycle trail is approximately 9 miles long, but bicycles are also permitted on the 8 miles of horse trails.  Because these are multi-use trails, be prepared to meet the occasional hiker, horseback rider, or park vehicle.  You'll feel like riding some more after completing the trail and the park's paved roads are perfect for that high speed riding you were unable to accomplish on the dirt trails!

trails.name: Rock Springs Reserve
trails.description: Technical single track and double track jeep roads meander through flat pine woods and palmetto prairies interspersed with cypress bogs.  Limited hunting.  Call first to find out hunting season status (407-884-2006).  This wild and beautiful area is good for biking during the dry months.  The Freewheelers scouted and cut a 12 mile loop trail and hope to add more trail in the future.  Look for the round blue blazes which mark the trail.  The scenic Rock Springs Run is on the southern boundary with Wekiva springs State park and is a good place to stop for a swim.  This is an area of both open palmetto thickets and woods.  Some sections of the bike trail is on existing roads which are shared with vehicles, equestrians and hikers while other sections are bicycle-only singletrack.

trails.name: Seminole Wekiva Markham Road Trail
trails.description: This is a new trail loop that needs to be ridden in.

trails.name: Markham Woods MTB trail
trails.description: from Green to Black these trail have a little bit of everything

trails.name: Lake Apopka Restoration Area
trails.description: The North Shore is pretty deserted no shade in either section, TONS of birds and aligators. The West end is nicer, has a loop and a cool narrow bridge and a coupe observation towers. Mostly hard packed maintenance roads, some grassy trails also, very flat welands.

trails.name: Ridgeline
trails.description:
This trail is ~2 miles of adrenaline-pumping fun. Consistently has natural mounds that vary in
height from roughly 10-20 feet. As long as you keep your speed up so you can make it up the
climbs, it is a fast, steep, up-and-down ride that is like a rollercoaster. It is not very techinal, for
the most part, but fast and flowy. The climbs are quite strenuous. It is considered Advanced
because of the steepness and speed. It has four short, optional offshoots that are more difficult
and even steeper. They also live up to their names. In order, they are: The Plunge, Corkscrew,
OMG, and Max G's.

trails.name: Best Fitness Software Development Services in USA | BCoder Castle
trails.description: If you are searching for the best software app development company in the United States, then you are at the right place. B-Coder Castle is well specializedFitness software Development Company that delivers the best fitness apps that can help customers to maintain their physical as well as mental health. Contact us at +1 (561)603-5184 or visit our website for more information.

trails.name: West Orange Trail
trails.description:
West Orange Trail
Just a few miles from metropolitan Orlando and Walt Disney World, the West Orange Trail is a central Florida attraction of a different sort. This world-class rail-trail, which travels through the communities of Winter Garden and Apopka, offers a rewarding experience and excellent facilities for the visitor. Among the highlights along the trail are a xeriscape/butterfly garden about a mile east of the Oakland Outpost, the Winter Garden Historical Museum and some picturesque views of Lake Apopka. The trail also provides access to and from Clarcona Horsemans Park, offering equestrians a staging area for their visit. The constant changes in scenery and the relaxed atmosphere of the towns along the way make this a great ride. This trail will eventually be a part of the 200 mile planned regional connection known as the Central Florida Loop.
-- http://www.dep.state.fl.us/gwt/guide/regions/eastcentral/trails/west_orange.htm --

trails.name: Orlando Mountain Bike Park
trails.description:
This small urban mountain bike park has been built at Lake Druid Park in a neighborhood close to downtown Orlando. The park includes a mountain bike area with a pump track, skills area with skinnies and wall ride, junior pump track and single track trail through the woods of approximately 1 mile of tight, twisty, but fairly easy trail. Beginner rated and great for kids, those getting started in the sport, and locals looking for some dirt.

The park is just getting started and plans for additional ST with more advanced options and skills area are planned for the future with more volunteer work.
Park news and info on volunteer days can be found here: https://www.facebook.com/Orlando-Mountain-Bike-Park-121589457912716/
Park Hours: 9 a.m. - half hour before sunset

trails.name: Soldier Creek Park
trails.description:
This 1.5 mile track is great for beginner and intermediate riders who want to learn dirt paths. Soldier Creek Trail follows along/around Soldier Creek and makes for interesting sight seeing while riding. The wood features are built well enough. The trail is pretty easy to follow. The parking lot reconstruction added a bike wash and repair station for riders. 

Overall, this trail is very good for riders who want to start learning a few technical skills without pushing it too far. There are a hills, flat land, and some jumps. The trail is short enough to loop a few times to try something different each time.

trails.name: Environmental Center
trails.description: Approximately five miles of single-track for intermediate to expert riders. On the other side of the street next to the ball fields is another single-track loop that runs along Soldier Creek. It is approximately a one and one-half mile loop. Both trails are excellent and can be crowded any day of the week due to its close proximity to Orlando.

trails.name: Helter Skelter
trails.description:
This track is the type of trail that you would find behind a Walmart. It's over grown and trashy. There is that feeling that someone is following behind you as you ride. Go in, get out as fast as you can.

Good climbs and a good ass kicking. Plenty of switchbacks. Don't sit down, you won't be ready for what's around the next turn.

trails.name: Mount Dora Trail
trails.description: Very fast and fun single track maintained by Ocala Mountain Bike Association. It has a main yellow loop with good flow and blue options throughout.  This is an intermediate trail due to it's speed and some tight spaces. It is very shaded and there are some amazing trees throughout.  The Red section is steep with some fast switchbacks and sudden drops.  Lots of fun with a little of something for most.  If you go to the Lincoln community park and go to the dog park the trail entrance is on the far end.

trails.name: Lake Jesup Wilderness Area
trails.description:
There are several miles of mixed use horse, mountain biking and hiking trails here. About half consists of
soggy, bumpy and often submerged double track. But if you slog it out from the trail head for about half a
mile you'll come to a surprise. Stretching about for half a mile to each side is a manmade raised berm
covered from end to end with large palm trees. And running down the middle is a hard packed trail. It is a
unique experience. The single track is a simple ride with fallen palm leaves, roots and tortoise holes to
negotiate. There are a few welcome breaks in the berm which drop back down to the soggy terrain for
about 30 feet and climb back up sharply on the other side. The south portion of the berm has a harder
packed trail and great views of Lake Jesup. At each end of the berm you'll find a loop which drops down to
the small naturally forested areas. The trail was dry here but still soft and not great for biking. Both loops
require you to cross a ditch with about a foot of nasty water to get back onto the berm. If you have
something you don't want swamp mud on you should leave it at home.

trails.name: Paisley Woods Trail
trails.description: Mostly flat singletrack with lots of miles and wildlife. About the halfway point there is a cut-trough to make it only a 10 mile loop. There are recreation areas at the north and south areas for a break. Look out for fallen trees, un-marked trails, sand, and even drifters.

trails.name: Blue Springs State Park
trails.description: A beginner trail for the area. Singletrack is relatively slow and twisty, but not difficult. They are all two-way singletrack trails and connected to each other. During the summertime the trail becomes very insect infested and you should prepare yourself for that.

trails.name: Lake Beresford Park Nature Trail
trails.description: Trail located within the Lake Beresford Park in DeLand, Florida. A 1.6 mile nature trail and 2 mile paved loop. Both the paved and nature trails allow bicycles as well as hiking. The track starts at the equine parking lot (Horses are allowed), but the address takes you to the main parking lot which has a playground, picnic pavilions and a full restroom. This is the park that one gains access to the Spring to Spring Trail from.

trails.description: Technical single track and double track jeep roads meander through flat pine woods and palmetto prairies interspersed with cypress bogs.  Limited hunting.  Call first to find out hunting season status (407-884-2006).  This wild and beautiful area is good for biking during the dry months.  The Freewheelers scouted and cut a 12 mile loop trail and hope to add more trail in the future.  Look for the round blue blazes which mark the trail.  The scenic Rock Springs Run is on the southern boundary with Wekiva springs State park and is a good place to stop for a swim.  This is an area of both open palmetto thickets and woods.  Some sections of the bike trail is on existing roads which are shared with vehicles, equestrians and hikers while other sections are bicycle-only singletrack.

trails.name: Chuck Lennon Park
trails.description: A great single track trail system that is very well marked. The trails provide an enjoyable ride for most all skilled riders. There are plenty of bailouts and bypasses for the challenging obstacles. There are currently 7 separate trails and a dirt jump area. There is also a small pump track with beginner level challenges. The wood features throughout the trails are built very well and most are coated with anti-skid paint. Plenty of drops and smooth turns throughout the trails. The advanced level Wild Turkey trail will put your skills to work with it's technical wood features, climbs and switchbacks. You won't leave disappointed with the variety at Chuck Lennon Park. Warning that heavy rains can cause some trails to close until they dry out.

trails.name: Environmental Center
trails.description: Approximately five miles of single-track for intermediate to expert riders. On the other side of the street next to the ball fields is another single-track loop that runs along Soldier Creek. It is approximately a one and one-half mile loop. Both trails are excellent and can be crowded any day of the week due to its close proximity to Orlando.

trails.name: Lake Jesup Wilderness Area
trails.description:
There are several miles of mixed use horse, mountain biking and hiking trails here. About half consists of
soggy, bumpy and often submerged double track. But if you slog it out from the trail head for about half a
mile you'll come to a surprise. Stretching about for half a mile to each side is a manmade raised berm
covered from end to end with large palm trees. And running down the middle is a hard packed trail. It is a
unique experience. The single track is a simple ride with fallen palm leaves, roots and tortoise holes to
negotiate. There are a few welcome breaks in the berm which drop back down to the soggy terrain for
about 30 feet and climb back up sharply on the other side. The south portion of the berm has a harder
packed trail and great views of Lake Jesup. At each end of the berm you'll find a loop which drops down to
the small naturally forested areas. The trail was dry here but still soft and not great for biking. Both loops
require you to cross a ditch with about a foot of nasty water to get back onto the berm. If you have
something you don't want swamp mud on you should leave it at home.

trails.name: Soldier Creek Park
trails.description:
This 1.5 mile track is great for beginner and intermediate riders who want to learn dirt paths. Soldier Creek Trail follows along/around Soldier Creek and makes for interesting sight seeing while riding. The wood features are built well enough. The trail is pretty easy to follow. The parking lot reconstruction added a bike wash and repair station for riders. 

Overall, this trail is very good for riders who want to start learning a few technical skills without pushing it too far. There are a hills, flat land, and some jumps. The trail is short enough to loop a few times to try something different each time.

trails.name: Wekiwa Springs State Park
trails.description:
Its a loop, but head west out of the parking area to access the bike trail.  It doesn't look like a trail, and the sign warns authorized vehicles only.  The singletrack portion of the trail is a little further down the trail and doubles as a hiking trail, but the senic diversity of the trail make running into the occational hiker well worth it.  You also have a great chance of seeing some wildlife.  Be aware of the red blazes that mark the trail, as you will easily get lost if you are not careful.  Once the shared trail ends, in order the continue the loop, one is forced onto a fire road/break.  Why this is a designated bike trail I'll never know.  Deep ruts and huge clods of dirt make riding impossible except on the edge of the bush.  You'll inevitibly end up walking your bike through the worst of it.  
The bicycle trail is approximately 9 miles long, but bicycles are also permitted on the 8 miles of horse trails.  Because these are multi-use trails, be prepared to meet the occasional hiker, horseback rider, or park vehicle.  You'll feel like riding some more after completing the trail and the park's paved roads are perfect for that high speed riding you were unable to accomplish on the dirt trails!

trails.description: It is a fairly flat beginner trail. It used to be an old road but is not maintained. The views are nice.

trails.name: Haile's Trails
trails.description:
This course is on private property and is only open a few of times a year by the landowners, don't miss the opportunity to ride this trail as the limited usage keeps it in great condition and the terrain is challenging for FL.  Expect a nominal fee to have access for the day when open.

Intermediate skill level riding, located around an old rock quarry, many elevation changes using the quarry terrain and medium to long climbs throughout.   Hardpack tread base, this course holds up well in rainy conditions except climbs can get very slick due to limestone, lots of singletrack with intermittent jeep roads, the area around the "widowmaker" section is the most demanding.  

This is a great trail to visit during race weekends, check www.goneriding.com for dates.

trails.name: Suwanee River from US 129 to 105th St.
trails.description: Part of Gainesville to Branford Corridor

trails.description: Part of Ichetucknee to O'Leno Trail

trails.name: Razorback Ridge
trails.description: A semi-technical XC trail built around, on and over a ridgeline of old canal diggings.

trails.name: Tricycle
trails.description: Under utilized new trail on the western edge of the the Santos system.  Badly in need of riding to become properly packed.

trails.name: Ern N Burn
trails.description: The trail is mostly on what looks like the diggings from an old barge canal. The trail is well made with plenty of bench cuts and the trail is re-enforced with shell in many areas. Because the trail takes advantage of the diggings there is plenty of quick elevation changes and nice flow.

trails.name: Troll
trails.description: A fast, flowing, testing trail with several short climbs, descents, and burms along with a couple drops that are packed into a short loop off the main Ern N' Burn trail.  On the west end of the extended Santos trail network this short loop is another reason to venture away from the main trail head when riding at Santos.

trails.name: Beyond
trails.description: This trail is part of the Ross Prairie section. It ia nice cross-country singletrack. Not much elevation change but you will be able to pick up some speed.

trails.name: Paradise Trail
trails.description: A beginner trail that is significant because it gives the Shangri-La camping area access to the Santos system.  Brand new trail that needs packed in.

trails.name: Pine Tree Loop
trails.description: Pine Tree Loop is a nice beginners loop that everyone in the family can enjoy. Every now and then there is the occasional root or rock but for the most part this is a flat and easy trail. The loop starts and ends at the Santos trailhead.

trails.name: Morris Bridge Park
trails.description: The bike tail begins behind the rest rooms, follow the footbridge under the road, then follow the two-track south. The trails are a little sandy in spots and it floods during heavy rains. If summer, spray yourself with anti-mosquito spray. Approximately 10-15 miles of trails. If you hook-up with someone who knows the area, they can connect you with another 10-15 miles of trails.

trails.name: Wilderness Trails Park Loop
trails.description: The main loop offers a good after work mileage loop. several other trails also connect to the main loop for even more mileage. Not a very exciting trail, but good for miles and a cardio workout.

trails.name: Flatwoods Park
trails.description: Paved trail

trails.name: Sydney Dover Trails
trails.description: This trail is shared with horses but they are there mostly on weekends. this is a good afterwork ride to get in a good 7 miles on mostly flat, wide double track with a couple climbs. There are some othe off shoot trails that offer a little more adventure.

trails.name: Colt Creek State Park
trails.description: The main trial is a multi-use trail that starts near a small lake, but quickly takes you into pine flatwoods.  The trail is well marked and easy to follow if you stay on the main loop.  The trail is mainly sand, which has been dug up in places by wild pigs, making some stretches very rough and very soft.

trails.description: Easy and scenic

trails.name: Kathryn Abby Hanna Park
trails.description: At least 10 miles of singletrack, possibly more. Many mile of hard pack, with a few areas of soft sand. It is pretty flat, but has some technical areas, a lot of switch backs. The trails are marked for beginner through expert. There are a large number of tree roots, which will beat up you and your bike.

trails.name: Egans Creek Greenway
trails.description:
There are free maps of the greenway at the trail head showing trails. The
trail is wide and simple on the green way and very family friendly. It makes
for a great ride at any pace. What you don't see on the map however is the
MTB trail off the greenway that is NOT directional. You can access this trail
from two ends and those trail heads are marked with signs. The MTB trail is
single track and has lots of roots (both small and some larger), narrow
spots, and some low branches. I would not recommend small children on
the MTB portion.

trails.name: Crusty Knuckle
trails.description: The area as a whole is certainly more fun than Hanna, with the trails being a stong-intermediate at best. The two new "bridges" that have been fashioned are very clever, and the jump near the beginning on the east side of Kernan adds a little "fear-factor" for the less-skilled rider as well. Synopsis? : The rolling hills on both sides are great fun as long as your at speed; the one large carpeted hill is a leg-churning endever; the tight areas between a few sections of trees are interesting if you're into them a bit too fast (my left shoulder still aches); and I didn't find the roots to be all that much of a major headache to maneuver around considering what STATE we're in! There are 10 miles of varying terrain out there, though it actually feels more like 4-to-5 when your done. The trails are definitely worth the time it takes to find them all, especially if you live in or around the Jacksonville area.  CUDOS to those that have made and try hard to maintain these trails. When you ride, take notice that the newer additions were all made of degradable material and will make no impact on the natural surroundings. The riders here also seem to take out what they bring in, so please respect the area and do the same.   Environmental Center

trails.name: Fort Clinch
trails.description: deep sand, roots

trails.name: Ft. Clinch State Park
trails.description: Good mountain biking.

trails.name: Losco
trails.description: Network of connecting double track loops. No technical features.

trails.name: Closes Gap Between Big and Little Talbot State Parks via A1A and Heckscher Dr.
trails.description: Part of East Coast Greenway - Duval County Corridor

trails.name: Panama City Beach Conservation Park
trails.description: Panama City Beach just opened a new park area for mountain biking, hiking, etc. There are 24 miles of trail in this network. The longest official loop is the 11 mile loop (Red Arrows).

trails.name: Crooked Creek
trails.description: This trail is flat and sandy in places. Can get overgrown in some areas. Not the best designed trail; some areas have a lot of turns/"switch backs" but because of the design you can't take at speed. There is a pavilion and bathroom at the trail head.

trails.name: Dutch Tiemann Trail
trails.description: This trail is not technical, nor is it aerobically challenging, but it is a fun ride.  I finished it and turned around and rode back in the other direction, completing the loop twice.  Navigating the trail is not hard at all and well maintained.  There's a $2 day use fee for the park, but well worth it.  I'd recommend this ride to anyone looking to get in a workout.  Nice woodsy scenery.  Crooked Creek Trail is located just down the road and is 9 miles long.  Combining these two rides in one day would be an awesome workout.

trails.name: Grayton Beach Recreational Park
trails.description: Beginning is duo track, winding through the odd but cool looking forest. Very flat but bumpy b/c the Yuca plant roots are exposed. Very curvy in some parts. Eventually dumps you out on access road for about 1/8 mile, walk the bike, too sandy. Singletrack then starts, go right or left off of the road. Very narrow, slightly sandy. Places that are too sandy, carpet has been laid down, about 2 feet across. The vegetation provides for a low pine tree canopy, but, the best parts it closes in around you and over you, making it very, very tight and slow, but challenging to keep your balance. Some places become so thick and low, long board walks snake through the large patches and 3 feet over the ground. Very enclosed. It's actually quite scenic, feels other worldly. Very leisurely. No climbs, no downs. It's a nice ride for a vacation @ the great beaches. It's worth it just for the odd vegetation and to get away from everybody. There will probably be nobody else back there, these were just constructed in spring '02. Leads to the better known East Lake trail that has a parking lot.

trails.name: Point Washington State Forest
trails.description: Trails are fun, mostly flat, twisty and somewhat sandy. There may be 20 miles of trails if one is willing to explore into Deer Lake State Park.  I'll say straight out that these trails aren't in my top ten list but they were a great save when I was into town for work and needed a nice ride.  On the plus side you can ride and then jump in the gulf!

trails.name: Longleaf Pine Greenway Trail
trails.description: This is 8 miles one-way, flat, all singletrack. Lots of fun. Very few sandy spots. If you combine this trail with Eastern Lake Bike Trail and Grayton Beach Recreational Park Mountain Bike Trail, you can do about 35 miles of trail in one area.

trails.name: Eastern Lake Bike Trail
trails.description: This trail is part of Point Washington State Forrest.  If you do the full loop (Orange), it will be 10+ miles.  But there are two shorter intersections that allow you to do 3.5 miles (Yellow) or 5.5 miles (Red).  The trail switches back and forth from double track logging road to singletrack.  There is no water at this place.  Maps are available at the Info Kiosk at the trail head.  This trail has LOTS of sand.  There are some sections that are practically unrideable.  You'd have to dismount and walk your bike through it.  For the most part, the intersections are well marked, but several are not completely clear - like they'll have a color in the middle of a 3-way T, but not tell you exactly which one to take.  Only after going a little ways down do you see another indicator.  In mountian biking, that's little more than a nuisance, but if I were cave diving, taking the wrong route because the paths are not marked well can get you killed.  It's a good ride and long enough to get in some exercise, but be warned about the sand!!!

trails.name: Timpochee Trail
trails.description:
Trail is on bike lane all the way - just follow Hwy 30A. Going thru the most prestigiuos beach resorts like Grayton Beach, Watercolors and Seaside (known from the Truman Story). http://bit.ly/9TRLgN

Bring sunscreen!!!

trails.name: Oleta River State Park
trails.description: Great Trail..... VERY technical trail. A whole lot of switchbacks....roots, rocks and more rocks. Turns with drop offs....whoops, and a lot more! Great Trail if you like technical. About 12 miles long. Good work out!

trails.name: Ocean View
trails.description: the trail is very fun, and its not an easy trail but there is a lot of hills and 10 foot trops, and you cant see it but its there, just ride through the front patch of woods and your in there for at least 10 min..

trails.name: Amelia Earhart Park
trails.description: This is a great park for novice riders and beginners, it is excellent to start getting the feeling for mountain biking. This park is known by very few people. The trails totally combine are about 7.25 miles long.

trails.name: Virginia Key North Point
trails.description: This is a brand new trail being constructed by funding from the city of Miami and a local business partners. Bernard "Frenchy'' Riviere is the trail builder behind the project. The system offers a little taste of everything including fun for both beginners and advanced riders. South Florida is becoming a serious MTB community with advocates pushing daily for more and better trails.

trails.name: West Delray Regional Park
trails.description: Complete trail with Intermediate, advanced, beginner, kids and jump sections.

trails.name: Vista View Park
trails.description: At 272 acres of green rolling hills and meadows, Vista View offers HILLS!!(not common in South Florida). The "Horse Loop" is about 1.4 miles with long climbs and fast and fun downhill sections. Great trail for training and a good workout. The trail loops the entire park, so you can access it from any of the parking lots. You have to share the trail with runners and the eventual horserider. There are plenty of places for family picnicking, an airstrip for radio-controlled plane and glider pilots, a dock for fishing, and an area for primitive group camping.

trails.name: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: A mixed use trail that runs approximately six miles through hardwood forest and cypress.  It's not a technically demanding ride and relatively flat, but the scenery is nice.  Check yourself for ticks when you're done.

trails.name: St. Marks Trail
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: This paved path runs 16 miles to the coast; about one mile or less from the start is a sand trail that runs into the woods, I think a four mile loop. Nice thing about this trail is that you can peel off and head into the National Forest. The trail is pretty tech at times dependent on the weather- the paved path is leisurely, and at the end @ St Marks is absolutely beautiful.

trails.name: Munson Hills
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: Update 6/7/13: This trail got a major upgrade in 2011. The vast majority of the trail was packed with layers of red clay, making the trail very hard and fast. There are now very few sandy areas. Turns have been banked and some moguls added. It's still not a technical trail, but it can be much faster than the description below implies, and there are still some nice tight areas to navigate. -VPJ Old Description: Trail is fairly easy. Sand in quite a few places that will sometimes firm up during the rainy season. Decent hills. Some good tight runs through the pine trees in a few places. There is also a designated short cut that will put the round trip at about 5 or 6 miles. Trail is fairly well marked but pay attention for there are quite a few illegal trails.

trails.name: Twilight Bike Trail
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: I stumbled onto this one while riding Munson Hills.  There is a West and East Connector trail that connects to Twilight.  To me, Twilight is nicer than Munson Hills.  It's fairly much a beginner trail in that there is no real technical stuff, but it's 9.5 miles long which is a good workout.  This trail goes behind the burms of the Crawfordville shooting range.  So they are actually shooting in your direction.  Gotta put lots of faith in those who engineered that place, huh?

trails.name: St Marks Lighthouse
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: This loop is for hiking or biking. Nice scenery, wildlife, etc. I used the paved road to complete my loop because one section of dams had not been mowed in a long time. Although it was ridable, I really didn't want to risk running over a snake in that high grass.  But this really is a good simple trail for a workout if you. A map can be picked up where you pay ($5) to get in. The St. Marks Unit of the St. Marks NWR is the location for the refuge head quarters and visitor center. A seven mile drive winds it way from the visitor center through fresh and brackish water impoundments and ends at the foot of the Apalachee Bay, near the historic St. Marks Lighthouse. Boat ramps, nature trails and a picnic area are located within this unit, and a road-side auto tour booklet is available for purchase in the visitor center. Uplands forests, forested swamps, fresh & brackish water marshes and a pristine salt water estuary ecosystem compose this unique area of Florida's Gulf Coast, making the St. Marks Unit a favorite for birders and outdoor enthusiasts alike.

trails.name: Kohls Trail
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: This is a very short trail that runs parallel to Blair Stone Rd.  In and of itself, it's nothing special, but can be a nice addition to a ride at nearby Tom Brown Park and / or Fern Trail.

trails.name: Fern Trail
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: The trail begins near Tom Brown Park, going underneath Capital Cir and paralelling the railroad tracks until you reach Governor's Park approximately in approx 1.6 miles.  The trail then loops back upon itself through Governor's Park for 1.4 miles.  It's a moderately difficult ride through urban forest and connects two major parks in the city.

trails.name: Loblolly Loop
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: The Loblolly trail is an optional route offered along the multi-use & West Cadillac trail and is easily accessed from the Lafayette Heritage Trail Park. It is a beginner level mountain bike trail totaling just under a mile. Very good first timer trail or warm up that leads into a slew of other trails.

trails.name: East Cadillac
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: The Cadillac Mountain Bike Trail is an overall intermediate skill level trail with sections that are expert level. Beginners can use options where provided to avoid expert sections. More Difficult sections are marked with a Black Diamond, or Double Black Diamond Symbol, and Intermediate Skill Areas are marked with a Blue Square Symbol. The trailhead and parking are located where the East/West trail sections meet.

trails.name: Bill's Trail
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: This trail runs along Piney Z Lake for approximately 1/2 mile from the JR Alford Greenway until stopping across the RR tracks from parts of the Lafayette Heritage Trail.

trails.name: Cadillac
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: Nice hills, up and down here.  Combine with TBP to have a killer ride.  Pretty technical and tight singletrack.

trails.name: J.R. Alford Greenway
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: This site is nestled between arms of Lake Lafayette.  There are over 17 miles of trails throughout the 870-someodd acre parcel.  Some are hard packed gravel and others (particularly those along the perimeter of the site) are unmaintained and rooty.  Trails wind through woods and rolling pasture.  A covered bridge over the RR tracks connects this system to  Lafayette Heritage Park.

trails.name: Tom Brown / Lafayette Heritage Park
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: This is the trail that Florida State Championships comes to yearly in Tallahassee.  It has been described as being as tough as the Olympics Park Trail in Atlanta.  It is a fun trail with plenty of ups and downs, however, recently the city has been closing off sections for maintenance.  When it is open, it is great.

trails.name: Timberlane School Rd Trail
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: This is a very short trail, but worth the ride at least once.  It's got some technical stuff on it like stream crossings, stumps, steep hill, trees to get over, man-made bridges, etc.  It hugs I-10 just a little before veering into the woods behind a subdivision.  Good quick workout.

trails.name: Live Oak
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: Not an officially sanctioned trail, but not officially "unsanctioned" either.  One of the tougher technical trails in town, with larger logs to clear with less helping sticks.  Large ravine gives a pretty gnarly down hill for about a 120 feet or so to the creek bed.  Not as well maintained, but great for a hard change of pace.

trails.name: Miccosukee Canopy Road Greenway
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: This is a nice trail to get a workout.  Some hills for aerobic workout.  No technical stuff.  Most of it is multi-use trail with some sections that go to singletrack on open field.

trails.name: Redbug
trails.parkName: Edward Ball Wakulla Springs State Park
trails.description: This is a great trail, I live in the area and ride it multiple times a week however like stated in previous review this is not the most technical trail in florida is is a 2/5 for technicality since most of the hard parts you can go around if desired. -Description by aewynn0915

trails.name: Scott Springs Park Trail
trails.description: A short loop that despite lack of rocks and roots is an intermediate ride that drops in and out of a retention pond, and has several small mounds and moguls..  Part of a park revitalization plan to place trails and skills parks thorough out the town.

trails.name: Briar Patch
trails.description: Fun, twisting, flowing side bar in the Santos adventure.

trails.name: Pine Tree Loop
trails.description: Pine Tree Loop is a nice beginners loop that everyone in the family can enjoy. Every now and then there is the occasional root or rock but for the most part this is a flat and easy trail. The loop starts and ends at the Santos trailhead.

trails.name: Rattlesnake Ridge
trails.description: A tight, technical red with a few great climbs and some sketchy ridgeline sections.

trails.name: Dog Bone
trails.description: This trail loops around the Vortex section of Santos. It is a beginners trail that flows nicely and you can really get some good speed going. There are really no elevation changes that are a challenge and the trail is mostly free of obstacles.

trails.name: Santos
trails.description: 81,290 acres of pure off-road riding bliss. Santos is the largest and best known mountain biking park in the Ocala, Florida area. Santos official designation is Marjorie Harris Carr Cross Florida Greenway.Greenwa**tretch many miles throughout the state of Florida.The greenway was born out of the failed Cross Florida Barge Canal which was terminated in the late 60s. Santos is named for the small town where the main trailhead is located. Standard trail markings are in place here - yellow trails ae beginner, blue intermediate and red markings for advanced. The majority of advanced riding is located around two abandonded mining pits. Trails range from flat and rolling to rocky and steep. The large network of trails can make it easy for the unintiated to get lost. Make sure to have a map and compass with you. Locals are always happy to help out with directions. The trail network is so extensive that you can spend a couple of days here and never tire of riding the evergrowing miles of singletrack.

trails.name: Sinkhole
trails.description: Probably the least technical red at Santos, however, faster and longer than the rest.  It's sits real close to the trailhead with little elevation changes, semi-technical switchbacks and has several short climbs and a number of somewhat technical rock sections.  It's situation between two blue trails, Marshmallow and Dr. Ruth acting as a great, technical connector.

trails.name: Dr Ruth
trails.description: This is a short intermediate trail that has a few rock gardens and lots of roots. The trail flows nicely and you can pick up some speed in some places. Not much in the way of climbing but you can still get a good burn.

trails.name: Marshmallow
trails.description: Flowing, beautiful forest trail.

trails.name: Cow Bone
trails.description: One of the better blue trails in the Santos system, Cow Bone starts close to the trailhead and will drop you off near a group of red trails including John Brown, Rattlesnake Ridge, and Anthill.

trails.name: Speedway
trails.description: Flowing, curvy off shoot trail.

trails.name: John Brown
trails.description: One of the more technical trails at Santos, John Brown is pumped full of heart pounding, leg pumping, singletrack action.  Great short, sketchy climbs and descents, big rocks and fairly decent ledges, semi-tight switchbacks. What more do you want?

trails.name: Canopy
trails.description:
Canopy is a short blue trail that intersects at the Marshmallow Trail and Pine
Tree Trail and has really some of the best scenery at Santos. It's name comes
from the incredible moss covered oak trees that extend over the trail creating
a "canopy" effect which is really breathtaking. One of those not so technical
trails, but you always love to ride.

trails.name: Twister
trails.description: Alot of good twisty singletrack. There are a few good drops in the beginning but other than that there are just gradual elevation changes. Flows nicely and you can really pick up some speed.

trails.name: Bunny
trails.description: This a fast flowing trail in Santos. Skilled riders will enjoy flying thru this trail and new riders will enjoy the twisty singletrack. There are not many obstacles so push the pedals and see how fast you can go.

trails.name: The Vortex
trails.description: Freeride zone with jumps, drops, and features. Many features are only open for events and competitions. There is a dedicated parking lot in the area, and you can also access from various trails through Santos.

trails.name: Imba Red
trails.description:
I believe this is the longest red out at Santos. It surrounds the
Freeride/Dirt Jump section and is loaded with action. It has several great
technical rock gardens, a few ladder ramps dumping you onto some gnarly
boulders, a few wood skinnies, etc. It's about 2 miles total but the trail
dumps you out onto the freeride area now and then and you'll re-enter to
continue. It's not hard to find you way in and out. The trail also has
several look outs where all the massive drops are.

trails.name: 12 Hours Of Santos Course
trails.description: Puppie, Twister, Vortex(Roller coaster in reverse, Dog Bone

trails.name: Anthill
trails.description:
This trail is one of the most technical trails at Santos, if not the most difficult. It is fairly short, less
than one mile, I believe. It is very rocky, especially for a Florida trail and it has a lot of quick,
STEEP up and downs.

trails.name: Razorback
trails.description: There are 2 loops : one short and one long. Plenty of climbs that let you earn your decents. Good fast singlrack. Varied terrain. Worth traveling from South Florida to go there. While in the area try Santos or Hardrock.

trails.name: Christmas Section
trails.description: The trail here is nice XC riding. Not a lot of obstacles or anything technical. Riders of all levels can enjoy the Christmas section. The trail passes thru pine and oak forests and a barren field that was logged. At the end of the trail you can take a few minutes to relax at the land bridge and turn around or continue on the more than 50 miles of trail at Santos.

trails.name: New Year's
trails.description: Basic central Florida XC trail with a bit of rolling landscape. An additional trail through the Christmas area of the Santos network provided a loop while riding that area.

trails.name: Nayles Trail
trails.description:
This is in the Shangri-La section of the network. Fun and fast, semi-technical,
cross country type trail that starts at 49th Avenue and brings you all the way
to CR 484. Most of the trail is wide open fast riding but does offer some
tighter, more technical sections with some slow gradual elevation changes
going both ways. Unlike the more popular Santos/Vortex sections, some areas
are susceptible to sugar sand during the dryer months, but overall it's fairly
hardpacked.

trails.name: Canal Diggings
trails.description: A short fun trail. OMBA does a great job using the old canal diggings. Very short loop but there is a bunch of stuff to play around with. Some nice quick elevation changes and some twisty singletrack.

trails.name: Troll
trails.description: A fast, flowing, testing trail with several short climbs, descents, and burms along with a couple drops that are packed into a short loop off the main Ern N' Burn trail.  On the west end of the extended Santos trail network this short loop is another reason to venture away from the main trail head when riding at Santos.

trails.name: Ern N Burn
trails.description: The trail is mostly on what looks like the diggings from an old barge canal. The trail is well made with plenty of bench cuts and the trail is re-enforced with shell in many areas. Because the trail takes advantage of the diggings there is plenty of quick elevation changes and nice flow.

trails.name: Paradise Trail
trails.description: A beginner trail that is significant because it gives the Shangri-La camping area access to the Santos system.  Brand new trail that needs packed in.

trails.name: Beyond
trails.description: This trail is part of the Ross Prairie section. It ia nice cross-country singletrack. Not much elevation change but you will be able to pick up some speed.

trails.description: Part of FNST Corridor

trails.name: Lake Seminole
trails.description: Lake Seminole holds over 37,500 acres of water and has over 18,000 acres of surrounding land. It borders both Georgia and Florida and sits in the heart of Chattahoochee. Recreational opportunities here include mountain biking, hiking, swimming, boating, canoeing, kayaking, fishing and camping.

trails.name: Moses Creek
trails.description: The trail has large sections with palm roots and some tight switchbacks which tend to slow the flow down on the first half of the trail.  There are also so great bridges and technical features currently and being built.  The second half of the trail has somewhat of a better flow (less palm roots- but unavoidable in NE Florida)Trail is fairly new so the path is being ridden in, however it is marked fairly well (bike signs and blue squares).

trails.name: Guana River State Park
trails.description: About 10 miles of mostly beginner and some intermediate scenic trail.  Completely flat.  Beginners will be right at home on these trails.  Intermediates will find trails to be easy, fun to ride in large groups, and good for introducing beginners.  Experts: You're going to the beach anyway so you might as well get a short ride in!  Not challenging at all.

trails.name: Mala Compra
trails.description: Mostly intermediate trail, with a few red sections towards the middle of the trail.  The trail has great canopy throughout and all hardpack, even in the middle of Florida's brutal summer.  The trail contains some pretty good short technical, challenging climbs followed by abrupt, shifty  descents.  You'll find a few little bridges over water and some really sweet ridge line sections with a couple areas leaving no margin for error.  Lots of roots towards the end of the trail, almost too much, a bit redundant after a while.  The trail is, for the most part, well marked, but a few areas are bit confusing and you may need to stop and think for a second.

trails.name: Nocatee
trails.description:
Update 2/24/14: SORBA JAX had a massive workday on Sat. Feb 22. The trails have been recut and reshaped. One wood skinny was constructed and one will be finished this weekend. The trail is soft and needs to be ridden. Signs will soon bee installed. Some new pictures have been put up. Sorba Jax just spent over 100 man hours on this trail. More Improvements are on the way. Update 8/12/12: This trail is currently under contruction and has a 3 mile loop of single track, with 4 bridges as of 8/12/12. Some of the trails still need some work. More miles of trail will be cut in the fall and spring time.

Also about 4 miles of Fire road that can be riden as well.
Facebok page: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Mala-Compra-Mtn-Bike-trail/134417869951121?sk=wall#!/pages/St-Augustine-Trail-Riders/260572137347422

john-pennekamp.parkName: John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park

trails.name: Southern Glades Trail
trails.parkName: John Pennekamp Coral Reef State Park
trails.description:
Terrain:  Largely flat but rough, can be technical where limestone is abundant.

The North trail is called Everglades Trail, the South trail is called the Southern Glades Trail.  This trail is very long and flat, but there is one hill of approximately 5 meters (18 ft) in height.  The trail is maintained in part by Miami Dade County, South Florida Water Management District, and the Everglades National Park.  It runs alongside the Southeastern border of the National Park and ends in a small bay called Manatee Bay.  The trail itself is composed of several loops which can total more than 50  miles.  Maps are available at the trailhead.

trails.name: Highlands Hammock State Park
trails.description: The trail is basically a double track that tours the state park.  It is not difficult and there isn't anything remotely challenging about the ride.  I camped here on a trip to Alafia River State Park, but there was rain in the forecast, so I rode here to beat the rain.  One of the loops ends on the paved auto tour with a bike lane.  I rode this also because it was there.  It was a fun ride in the sense that I saw more of the park than I would have otherwise.

trails.name: The Preserve
trails.description: Single track and fire roads. Some areas are very technical cardiac means high cardia workout.

trails.name: Carlton Preserve
trails.description:
Trail is now open. This is a new trail system the SCORR (Sarasota Charlotte county Off Road Riders) Just built last spring and has been under water most of the summer. If you want to experience Florida riding at it's best, now is the time. You will get your feet a little wet, it will be 5 challenging miles, you'll get your heart rate up, your bike will get dirty, but you'll end up with a smile on your face.
Carlton Preserve
1800 Mabry Carlton Pkwy, Venice, FL 34292

trails.description: Flat Singletrack good amount of twists turns and roots.

trails.name: The Celery Fields
trails.description: This trail is great for short rides before or after work. They have cut some new trails along the side that make it so you don't have to walk your bike up the mound the whole time.

trails.name: Kathryn Abby Hanna Park
trails.description: At least 10 miles of singletrack, possibly more. Many mile of hard pack, with a few areas of soft sand. It is pretty flat, but has some technical areas, a lot of switch backs. The trails are marked for beginner through expert. There are a large number of tree roots, which will beat up you and your bike.

trails.name: Crusty Knuckle
trails.description: The area as a whole is certainly more fun than Hanna, with the trails being a stong-intermediate at best. The two new "bridges" that have been fashioned are very clever, and the jump near the beginning on the east side of Kernan adds a little "fear-factor" for the less-skilled rider as well. Synopsis? : The rolling hills on both sides are great fun as long as your at speed; the one large carpeted hill is a leg-churning endever; the tight areas between a few sections of trees are interesting if you're into them a bit too fast (my left shoulder still aches); and I didn't find the roots to be all that much of a major headache to maneuver around considering what STATE we're in! There are 10 miles of varying terrain out there, though it actually feels more like 4-to-5 when your done. The trails are definitely worth the time it takes to find them all, especially if you live in or around the Jacksonville area.  CUDOS to those that have made and try hard to maintain these trails. When you ride, take notice that the newer additions were all made of degradable material and will make no impact on the natural surroundings. The riders here also seem to take out what they bring in, so please respect the area and do the same.   Environmental Center

trails.name: Egans Creek Greenway
trails.description:
There are free maps of the greenway at the trail head showing trails. The
trail is wide and simple on the green way and very family friendly. It makes
for a great ride at any pace. What you don't see on the map however is the
MTB trail off the greenway that is NOT directional. You can access this trail
from two ends and those trail heads are marked with signs. The MTB trail is
single track and has lots of roots (both small and some larger), narrow
spots, and some low branches. I would not recommend small children on
the MTB portion.

trails.name: Anderson Springs
trails.description: The riverside track follows the Suwannee River for two miles, including a stretch of limestone outcrops and some shoals. Some of this trail is on the Florida trail, so be courteous to hikers. North end of the river section is an old hunt camp. You can do 7 to 10 miles of riding, depending on which trails you take. The Suwannee Bicycle Association is planning to development more singletrail in the area. Contact: wpburden@aol.com "Westside Regional Park

trails.name: Holton Creek
trails.description: Bike or hike through old growth forest 16 miiles in an area dubbed, "Land of a Thousand Sinks." Woodland roads go for many miles along the river. Visit Holton Creek thought to be one of the rises of the disappearing Alapaha River.

trails.name: Allen Mill Pond
trails.description: The route follows old jeep roads to the southern boundary of the Tract and north to the spring. Round trip is 4.2 miles of forest roads. Contact: wpburden@aol.com

There are free maps of the greenway at the trail head showing trails. The
trail is wide and simple on the green way and very family friendly. It makes
for a great ride at any pace. What you don't see on the map however is the
MTB trail off the greenway that is NOT directional. You can access this trail
from two ends and those trail heads are marked with signs. The MTB trail is
single track and has lots of roots (both small and some larger), narrow

trails.name: Etowah Park Naval Submarine Base
trails.description: This trail in on an open to the public part of the Naval Submarine Base in Kingsbay, Ga. It is basically a bunch of fire roads that lead out and back. Only thing about it that is hard is that it is covered in foilage. Nice ride for the kids and beginners. There is a boat ramp and a camp site, but to camp there you must contact MWR at Kingsbay NSB.

trails.name: Crooked River State Park
trails.description: Trail is mostly flat, good for stretching out those muscles and riding flat out on a wide easy trail. It's also good for younger riders that are just learning and you are wanting them to get into something. There are 3 different trail systems that can connect into one big loop. Each trail has its own name, Palmetto Trail, Sempervirens Trail, and the Bay Board Walk Trail. The Trails are relatively flat and not hard. The Sempervirens Trail is very rooty, but easily navigated through.

trails.name: Fort George
trails.description: Easy and scenic

trails.description: Part of Amelia Island Parkway Path

trails.name: Fort Clinch SP Along S 8th St. and Atlantic Ave
trails.description: Part of East Coast Greenway to Georgia Trail Corridor
